Some of the comments bring out a major problem with educational testing. When test scores are available, students and the schools tend to be evaluated solely on the basis of those scores.

This problem is not restricted to education. It is a tyranny of numbers that detracts from the benefits of quantification in any area.

Test results can measure the primary purpose of education, but intuitively we would like to see the development of morality, personal character, social sensitivity, and civic sense as well. These other qualities are not easily quantified, and need to be actively protected from the tyranny of test scores.

In my opinion, rather than serving as a counter example Google actually proves David's point. Some of Google's software is high quality (search engine, gmail, maps) but some products are pretty disappointing. Android is a perfect example -- Google put it out there before it was anywhere close to finished and several years later it is still full of bugs. I have just seen a review of Android 4.0 saying "Ice Cream Sandwich is a great release from which to build on, but plenty of rough edges remain". Pretty much guarantees that my next phone is not going to run Android.

Finally a semblance of good sense from the administration on immigration.  Americans have little idea of just how dysfunctional our immigrant visa programs are in comparison to the rest of the world.  While we admit millions per year based simply on common DNA with an American (who most probably immigrated themselves 5 to 10 years ago), the rest of the developed world is cherry-picking the best candidates out there.  Bringing in immigrants with the millions to invest in businesses that employ Americans is good for everyone.  We need to ditch the family preference categories (not immediate relative category) and the diversity visa program, which is a fraudsters' dream, and establish a point system immigration category much like what Canada has to bring us the best and brightest.  Think about this statistic for one minute:  we issue 50,000 diversity visas each year to people from around the globe who have zero connection to our country and its values.  That is 50,000 principal applicants (PA)!  So if each PA has a family size of 5, we are bring 250,000 immigrants to the U.S. each year based on nothing more than some misguided sense of openness at a cost of millions to taxpayers (DV immigrants do not have sponsors). The EB-5 category mentioned here speaks of allowing in 3500 immigrants a year.  We should allow 35,000 EB-5s per year!!!

And I believe that pigs fly!

The NFL commissioner is responsible for protecting the safety of the players, but he has gone too far in changing the kickoff rules. This season, the kickoff team starts from their own 35 yard line instead of their 30 and the kickoff team is allowed a 5 yard running head start before the kickoff. As a result, through week 13 of the season, 46% of kickoffs have been touchbacks, which is a large increase from 19% last year. One of the plays with great potential for excitement has been taken from the game because of concerns for safety.

I understand the need for safety as a general rule with the NFL, especially given how many injuries occur during a season. However, the commissioner’s rule change ignores that these are grown men who are being paid significant money to abuse their bodies and fans are paying a lot of money to see these games. Taking away the kickoff is like shortening a movie or shrinking a potato chip package. If we’re not getting as much for our dollar, and as a result, the NFL ought to lower ticket prices. Otherwise, please put the rules back so we can see kickoff excitement once again!

It seems worthwhile here to articulate "The Jurisprudence of the Carrot and the Stick"

There are two types of authority: Type A is Perceived Legitimacy/Moral Authority, aka soft power. Then there is Type B: Coercive/Santioning Authority - aka force, aka hard power.

Type A (moral authority): takes a very long time to accumulate, but is extremely inexpensive to wield and more sustainable, but it is inexpediant and not always decisiveness.

Type B (Coercive authority): is expediant, often decisive, but extremely expensive to wield.

Wise rulers then, trade some of Type B for a boat load of type A to be utilized where expediance does not buy decisiveness.

The first order for a would be brigand turned war lord, largely on the strength of coercive authority is to achieve moral authority to rule, and thereby reduce the coat of perpetuating ones rule while increasing the cost to any usurpers. The second order is secure the same for ones off spring.

In Europe the leader of a band of barbarians would do all of this by embracing Christianity, the religion of the Romans. In exchange Christian clerics anointed the King.

In Korea the highest prestige comes with being a scholarly mandarin. The greatest Korean King was Sejong who invented the the Korean alphabet. Kim Il-Sung created Juche a faux philosophy, attempting a sort of Marcus Aurelious. It was all for show, the Kim family regime relied on coercive authority, and the expense of that authority drove the country into poverty.
